Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: Issuing a parking ticket where discretion could be applied fairly
Story:
I glanced at my phone during my patrol shift, noticing a text from my mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Call when you can.” I hadn’t replied to her last message, and guilt pricked at me. She always wanted to hear from me, especially since I started working nights. I promised her I’d check in more, but the job always seemed to get in the way.

As I walked my beat, I spotted a car parked in a no-parking zone. The driver was an older woman, struggling with grocery bags. She reminded me of my mom. Technically, I should issue a ticket, but I had some discretion. My duty demanded fairness—if I let her go, was I being too lenient? If I ticketed her, was I being too harsh? My phone buzzed again. Another message from Mom: “Just want to know you’re safe.” I felt torn, the weight of my badge on one side, my mother’s gentle concern on the other. I stood there, ticket book in hand, wrestling with what was right—for my job, and for the daughter I was supposed to be.
